of appeals a there is created a civil service board of appeals consisting of nine 9 members who shall be residents of the city which board shall be the official protector of the civil service system the civil service board of appeals shall be empowered to hold hearings when requested by an employee of the city regarding proposed demotions suspensions dismissals or other such actions and shall have such powers to dispose of such cases as shall be provided by ordinance b members of the civil service board of appeals shall be selected in accordance with section 4106 of the charter and in accordance with the citys code of ethics members of the civil service board of appeals shall not be elected officials persons appointed to elective office fulltime appointed officials whether exempt or nonexempt or city employees nor shall they be currently serving on any other city board or commission no former mayor or former councilmember may be eligible for appointment as a member of the civil service board of appeals until one 1 year after the expiration of the term for which such official was elected c prior to commencement of service on the board and at least biannually thereafter each member will receive and attend training with the purpose of enhancing the board members ability and consistency in performing the members duties such training shall include applicable law and ordinances procedural conduct of hearings resolution of employment disputes evidence and such other topics as may be deemed advisable d the civil service board shall be provided with staff support by the city e the board shall conduct its business in the manner provided by the charter and shall perform the following functions 1 hold hearings when requested by an employee or an appointing authority on proposed demotions suspensions without pay dismissals or other such adverse actions with reference to the classified service and have power to make final determinations and dispositions in such matters  2 establish guidelines for hearing any matters referred thereto by the personnel department or employees  and 3 keep minutes of its meetings and such other record as it may deem necessary  31708 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning a adverse action means a disciplinary action taken for cause by the city manager or a department head which results in suspension without pay demotion or dismissal of a regular permanent nonprobationary employee in the classified service of the city as defined in  it does not include actions which result from challenging the decision to implement or the scope of a layoff as defined in section 41060 or actions resulting from insufficient funds decrease in funds or departmental reorganization or denial of annual merit pay increase based on the employee receiving a less than satisfactory performance evaluation adverse actions are appealable to the civil service board of appeals b appeal means a written request by an employee for review by the civil service board of appeals of an adverse action c appointing authority means the city manager or department head having the power of appointment demotion or election to or removal from subordinate positions in the city employment service d board means the civil service board of appeals of the city of east point e classified service means all positions not specifically included in the unclassified service by this classified position is a position in the classified service f days unless otherwise specified means business or week days g demotion means a change of employment to a position in a class which has a lower maximum salary limit than the class from which the assignment was made a reduction in pay shall not be deemed a demotion for cause if such reduction results from a demotion during a probationary period such that the employee is returned to his or her former position or to a position with comparable salary a layoff due to insufficient funds decrease in funds departmental reorganization or a change of appointment made in the discretion of the appointing authority as provided by this shall not be appealable under this article h disciplinary action means an action taken for cause by the city manager or a department head which results in an oral warning a written reprimand demotion suspension with or without pay or dismissal of a regular permanent nonprobationary employee in the classified service of the city disciplinary actions include all adverse actions only those disciplinary actions which are adverse actions suspension without pay demotions or dismissals by definition of this article are appealable to the civil service board of appeals i dismissal means the discharge termination or removal of an employee from employment with the city j grievance means a written request by an employee for review of an allegation which describes a workrelated event or a condition of employment which the employee reasonably believes is unfair in light of the rules regulations and standards which govern the employment relationship with the city grievances are not adverse actions within the meaning of this chapter and are not appealable to the civil service board of appeals k hearing officer means a member of the civil service board of appeals appointed in accordance with charter section 4106 and who is designated in routine rotating sequence to hear appeals filed with the board l hearing panel means three 3 members of the civil service board of appeals who are designated in routine rotating sequence to hear appeals of dismissals filed with the civil service board m oral warning means a verbal discussion by a department head or supervisor with an employee calling attention to the employees substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct and requiring correction of the substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct within a specified timeframe an oral warning shall not constitute an adverse action within the meaning of this chapter n performance evaluation means a periodic written report approved by the appointing authority or designee relative to the workrelated conduct and performance of the employee and which is issued in accordance with this chapter a negative performance evaluation shall not constitute an adverse action within the meaning of this chapter o probationary employee means any employee appointed to a permanent position who has not completed the required probationary period in a given class p reprimand means a written report to an employee by a department head or supervisor calling attention to the employees substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct and requiring correction of the substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct within a specified timeframe a written reprimand shall not constitute an adverse action within the meaning of this chapter q separation means termination of the employment relationship as described in  r suspension means the temporary removal of an employee from a position of employment with the city with or without pay  31708 right to file appeal a any permanent employee in the classified service of the city against whom adverse action is proposed ie suspension without pay demotion or dismissal shall have the right to appeal the action as provided in this article b an employee against whom any adverse action is proposed desiring to appeal such action shall initially appeal for a hearing before the city manager by filing notice of such appeal on or before  pm of the fifth business day after the employee receives notice of the proposed adverse action against him or her the city manager shall render a written decision within five business days following such hearing c in the event of an appeal to the city manager by an employee against whom an adverse action is proposed the withholding of wages salary or dismissal based upon the adverse action shall be abated pending a hearing before the city manager such abatement shall only be in effect until a decision is rendered by the city manager in accordance with this code section d an employee who having first appealed a proposed adverse action to the city manager pursuant to subparagraph a of this code section is dissatisfied with the determination of the city manager shall have the right to appeal to the civil service board of appeals in accordance with section 41013 e unless otherwise provided all appeals to the civil service board of appeals are entitled to a hearing which shall be conducted by a hearing officer of the civil service board of appeals pursuant to this article however with the written consent of all parties and the approval of the hearing officer a hearing may be waived and the appeal considered on the written record  31708 notice of appeal a time for filing appeal all employee appeals of adverse actions to the civil service board shall be initiated by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager in accordance with the procedures established under this article unless otherwise provided the notice of appeal shall be filed with the city manager or postmarked within five business days after the later of 1 the date when the employee receives final written notice of the action or decision from the city manager or the date final notice from the city manager is delivered by certified mail to the employees lastknown address 2 the effective date of the action or decision of the city manager b the notice of appeal shall be considered timely if postmarked within the time allowed for an appeal but shall not be considered filed until actually received by the city manager untimely appeals shall be summarily dismissed by the board c transmittal of copies of notice within city and assignment to hearing officerpanel upon receipt of the notice the city manager shall immediately transmit a true copy of the notice to the employees department head the city manager shall assign the appeal for hearing by a hearing officer of the civil service board in the normal rotation of hearing officer assignments as provided in section 41014  31708 civil service board members serving as hearing officers a hearing officers for the purposes of holding hearings on appeals and otherwise assisting in the resolution of appeals under this article individual member of the civil service board of appeals shall serve as individual hearing officers in a dismissal a panel of three board members shall be convened for the purpose of hearing the dismissal notwithstanding any other authority and duties given to the civil service board members as individual hearing officers they shall receive and compile evidence prepare findings of fact render written decisions and the basis therefore certify records and make investigations of matters under the jurisdiction of this article where a review is appropriate b assignment of hearing officers to appeals upon appointment to the civil service board the appointees name shall be placed in the alphabetical listing of civil service board members for the purpose of being assigned appeals as scheduled by the city manager appeals will be assigned according to hearing officers in a continual alphabetical rotation of names  31708 authority and duties of hearing officerspanels any duly appointing hearing officerpanel shall have the authority to do the following in connection with any hearing under this article a administer oaths and affirmations to witnesses appearing before the board b regulate the course of the hearing c set the time and place for continued hearings and prehearing conferences which shall be in a location owned or operated by the city d fix the time for filing written arguments as deemed appropriate e dispose of motions to dismiss for lack of the boards jurisdiction over the subject matter or parties or for any other grounds f dispose of motions to amend or to intervene g provide for the taking of testimony by deposition or interrogatory h reprimand or exclude from the hearing any person for any indecorous or improper conduct committed in the presence of the hearing officer i make informal disposition of any case by stipulation agreed settlement consent order or default unless such disposition is precluded by law j render a final decision in writing based upon the witnesses and evidence introduced at the hearing  31708 hearing procedures under this article the following are established to provide uniform procedures for the conduct of hearings by the board or hearing officer appointed by the board a notice of hearing the hearing shall be held within thirty 30 days after receipt of the notice of appeal by the city manager within ten days prior to the date for which the hearing is set the city manager shall designate from an alphabetical rotation system a hearing officerpanel of the civil service board and an appropriate time and place to conduct the hearing and shall so notify all parties in writing such notification shall be mailed or served at least ten days prior to the date for which the hearing is set any hearing officerpanel shall have the authority to postpone or to continue a hearing upon its own motion or upon the motion of either party b representation opportunity shall be afforded both parties to obtain legal representation all arrangements for providing legal counsel shall be the responsibility of the party desiring such representation only representatives of employee organizations recognized by the city in accordance with section 41024 of this code may provide nonlawyer representation to an employee the city attorney may represent the appointing authority c prehearing conference the hearing officerpanel may arrange a prehearing conference for the purpose of reviewing the matter being appealed and establishing stipulations to expedite the hearing d witnesses the employee or the department may request the attendance of employees or other persons as witnesses when their testimony will aid in establishing the facts in the case employees appearing as witnesses shall be released from duty without the loss of pay or time and without effect on their service rating no person shall directly or indirectly use or threaten to use any official authority or other influence which would tend to discourage any other person from testifying e subpoenas 1 request for subpoena the employee the city manager the employees department head or the hearing officerpanel may request the city clerk to issue subpoenas for witnesses for hearings the cost for securing the attendance of witnesses who are noncity employees including fees or mileage shall be computed and assessed in the same manner as prescribed by law for civil cases in the superior court 2 issuance of subpoenas subpoenas shall be issued without discrimination between public and private parties when a subpoena is disobeyed any party in the matter may apply to the superior court of the county in which the hearing is being held for an order requiring obedience failure to comply with such order shall be cause for punishment as for contempt of court 3 quashing or limiting subpoenas once issued a subpoena may be quashed or limited by the hearing officerpanel upon the motion of the hearing officerpanel or any party or at the request of the witness if it appears that the subpoena was used primarily as a means of harassment that the testimony or documents sought are cumulative that the testimony or documents sought are not relevant or material that to respond to the subpoena would be unduly burdensome or that for other good reasons basic fairness dictates that the subpoena should not be enforced f record of hearing a certified court reported shall be engaged by the city to provide a takedown of all hearings  however the recording of a hearing shall not be transcribed unless approved by the city manager if the transcription is so made pursuant to a request by either party in the hearing the cost thereof shall be borne by the party making the request in addition to the recording of the hearing of the transcription thereof all documents entered into the record during the hearing shall be made part of the official record of the hearing g appointing authoritys opportunity to be heard at the request of the appointing authority or at the invitation of the hearing officerpanel or the board the appointing authority or that officials designee shall be entitled to be heard and to submit evidence in any appeal in which the interpretation of a civil service rule regulation policy or practice is at issue h the chief of police may assign and upon request by the city manager shall assign a police officer to attend all hearings of the civil service board of appeals and in all hearings the police officer in attendance at the hearing shall enforce and carry out all lawful orders of the city manager or the hearing officerpanel and anyone violating such orders shall upon conviction thereof in the city of east point court be punished as provided for in section 11006 of this  31708 conduct of hearing in the hearing of an appeal under this article the proceeding shall be informal but orderly the following procedure shall prevail a the hearing officerpanel shall open the hearing by explaining the procedure to be followed in the hearing at the discretion of the hearing officerpanel any or all witnesses may be sequestered b the hearing officerpanel shall read or cause to be read the charges and specifications as contained in the notice of appeal as filed with the city manager any written response to the notice of appeal as filed with the city manager shall then be read by agreement these documents may be inserted in the record without reading c the facts not in dispute shall be stipulated d each party shall be given the opportunity to make a brief opening statement identifying the issues and stating what is to be proven e all witnesses shall testify under oath or affirmation f each party may conduct such examination of the witnesses as shall be required for a full and true disclosure of the facts in addition the hearing officer may examine the witnesses g official notice may be taken of facts generally recognized by the public in addition official notice may be taken of technical facts within the specialized knowledge of the hearing officer parties shall be notified either before or during the hearing by reference in preliminary reports or otherwise of the material officially noted including any staff memoranda or data and they shall be afforded an opportunity to contest the materials so noticed h the hearing officerspanels experience technical competence and specialized knowledge may be utilized in the evaluation of evidence i before closing the hearing the hearing officerpanel shall allow both parties the opportunity to make brief oral or written closing statements j the hearing officerpanel who presided shall within fifteen 15 days from the close of the evidence issue a decision however for good cause the time may be extended for rendering a decision but in no case shall exceed an additional fifteen 15 days the decision shall be to the city manager the affected department head and the appealing employee or their representatives the hearing officerspanels decision shall become final and there shall be no right to any additional administrative appeals  31708 evidence and attendance at the hearing a evidence with respect to all hearings before the board or the hearing officerpanel under this division the following rules regarding the evidence shall govern 1 formal legal rules of evidence shall not be strictly applied evidence may be admitted if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs the hearing officerpanel shall follow the state rules of evidence regarding privileges recognized by the law of the state 2 irrelevant immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence may be excluded 3 objections to evidentiary offers may be made and shall be noted in the record 4 when a hearing will be expedited and the interest of the parties will not be prejudiced substantially any part of the evidence may be received in written form including but not limited to the use of depositions or interrogatories 5 documentary evidence may be received in the form of copies if the original is not readily available upon request and at the discretion of the hearing officerpanel parties shall be given the opportunity to compare the copy with the original document b attendance at hearing upon the motion of either party the hearing officerpanel may close the hearing of any appeal under this article as provided by ocga  501436 or by any federal privacy statute an appeal file containing evidence received in a closed hearing shall not be included in a public record  31708 decision of hearing officerpanel a requirements of decision as part of the final decision the hearing officerpanel shall include findings of fact and any law on which the decision is based separately stated and the effective date of the decision or order findings of fact shall be accompanied by a concise and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings copies of the decision or order shall be mailed to all parties of record by the city manager b finality of decision the decision of the hearing officerpanel shall be binding on both parties the hearing officerpanel may modify the adverse action of the appointing authority but may not increase the severity of such action on the employee the appointing authority shall promptly comply with the final decision as may be issued as a result of the appeal c relief of employee if the decision of the hearing officerpanel is in favor of the employee on appeals of dismissal suspension or demotion the employee shall be reinstated in accordance with the decision to the classification from which the employee was removed the effective date of the reinstatement shall be the date immediately following the effective date of the appealed action as if there had been no break in service unless otherwise specified in the order the employee shall be entitled to the same salary with any increments in the position or salary which would have automatically inured to the employee if the employee had remained in actual service the employee shall receive payment as if there had been no break in service minus any amount earned by or paid to the employee from other employment and wage substitutions including but not limited to unemployment compensation during the period off the job and minus any amount paid the employee for annual leave sick and annual leave shall be restored to the employee in the same amount that existed at the time of the appealed action plus sick and annual leave that would have been earned for the period if the employee had actually been in service however any period of postponement or continuance of the hearing for the convenience of the employee shall be excluded from any payment of benefits due and this period of time shall be considered as if the employee had been on leave without pay prior to any payment to the employee the employee shall certify under oath the amount of any income received from other employment and any wage substitutes received during the period off the job which shall be deducted from the backpay owed by the city d the decision of the hearing officerpanel under this division shall not limit the right of either party to judicial review and such decision shall be stayed by the filing of a petition for review any party including the city or any city department who has exhausted all administrative remedies available before the board and who is aggrieved by a final decision or order of the board on any hearing may seek judicial review of the final decision or order of the board in the superior court of fulton county by writ of certiorari  31708 dismissal of appeal upon the motion of either party or upon its own motion the hearing officer or panel may dismiss any appeal under this division prior to holding a full hearing of the appeal upon the following conditions a the employee failed to exhaust administrative remedies by first appealing to the city manager as provided by section 41012c  b the appeal is clearly moot  c the appeal is without merit  d the appeal is untimely  e the appeal was not properly filed with the city manager  or f the appeal is not within the scope of the hearing officerspanels authority  31708 article c  personnel rules and regulations footnotes  2  editors note personnel rules and regulations is derived from the at the same or no cost to other members of the general public b it is particularly important that inspectors contracting officers and enforcement officers refrain from relationships which might be construed as creating an interference of favoritismcoercion unfair advantage or collusion political activity a employees of the city are encouraged to exercise their right to vote but no employee political candidate political party or political cause b any employee who has qualified or seeks to qualify for any elected office shall comply with the following provisions 1 within three 3 days of and what steps will be taken to meet the employees job responsibilities if elected 2 provide notice to the personnel director city manager and city council of his qualification or intent to qualify and seek elective office together with the office to which election is sought 3 provide notice of the date the employee will take leave of absence by vacation or leave without pay in the event process in the event any city employee is seeking an office should succeed to a runoff election the leave of absence hereinabove provided shall extend period of time of any such runoff election or primary runoff 4 any city employee seeking election to an elective office as part of the governing authority of the city either mayor or city council shall be required upon election to such office to governing authority of the city the employee shall be required to show proof satisfactory to the city manager and approval upon the city managers recommendation by the city council showing that the employee will not be required to devote any portion of his time in his capacity as employee of the city to serve or fulfill his function and obligations by virtue of his elected position  or take leave from employment with the city either with or without pay depending upon availability of such leave not including sick leave or resign employment with the city 6 in the event a city employee is of election has any contractual relationship with the city notwithstanding the provisions of subparagraph b5 above the employee shall be required to resign employment with the city effective as of the date of taking office or the position to which such employee is elected or in any other manner assuming the responsibilities of said elective position or office in the event during the interim period of time from election to taking office the city manager is not satisfied that the employee will not be devoting any portion of his time in his capacity as an employee of the city to said elected post such employee to such office has since established a contractual relationship with the city  2 5382 editors note the amendments to subsections b3 and 6 as enacted by will become effective on approval by the federal justice department civil rights division definition of classification plan the classification plan is the systematic grouping of positions into appropriate classes 1 a position is a group of current assigned duties and responsibilities requiring the full or part time employment of one person a position may be occupied or vacant 2 a class is a group of positions or one position that a has similar duties and responsibilities  b requires like qualifications  and c can be equitably compensated by the same range of pay 3 the class title is the official designation or name of the class and it shall be used on all personnel records and transactions use of class specifications specifications are to be interpreted in their entirety and in relation to others in the classification plan particular phrases or examples are not to be isolated and treated as a full definition of a class specifications are descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed maintenance of the classification plan the personnel director under the direction of the city manager shall maintain the classification plan so that it will reflect the duties performed by each employee in the classified service he or she shall periodically review the entire classification plan and recommend appropriate changes in allocations or in the classification plan reclassification shall not be abused or used to impose disciplinary action upon an employee allocation of positions when a new position is established or duties of an existing position change the department head involved shall submit in writing a position description stating the duties and responsibilities of the position the personnel director shall investigate the actual or proposed duties and recommend to the city manager the appropriate class allocation or the establishment of a new class the city manager then shall approve or change the recommendations and allocate the position to a class allocation appeals an employee who considers his position improperly classified shall submit his reclassification request in writing to his supervisor who shall make a recommendation to the personnel director within seven 7 days of receipt of the appeal the personnel director shall proceed as outlined in section 41030 of this article classification plan in effect the classification plan shall be considered a part of this section and shall have the same force and effect as these personnel rules and regulations a certified copy of the classification plan shall be maintained by the personnel director and filed with the city clerk reclassification a in situations of reclassification to a higher grade and pay range the employee shall be granted a pay increase equal to at least the first step of the new pay grade and in no case less than a onepaystep increase b in the situation of a reclassification to a lower pay grade the employee shall receive no salary reduction but shall be compensated at a pay step equal to the employees present pay or if the new reclassified pay grade is less than the employees present pay the employees pay shall remain the same until the newly reclassified pay grade exceeds the employees present pay composition of pay plan the pay plan includes the adopted salary schedule and the schedule of salary ranges consisting of rates of pay for all classes of positions included in the classification plan maintenance of the pay plan the pay plan is intended to provide fair compensation for all classes in the classification plan considering range of pay for other classes  rates of pay for comparable services in private and public employment in the area  the citys financial condition and policy and other factors the personnel director shall at least annually make or cause to be made comparative studies of all the factors affecting the level of salary ranges as appropriate entrance salary the minimum rate established for this class is the normal hiring rate appointments under special conditions and subject to the prior approval of the city manager may be made above the minimum rate when such action is determined to be necessary in the best interest of the city approval will be based on such conditions as shortage of qualified applicants available at the minimum step and qualifications of the applicant being in excess of the requests for the class reserved editors note  adopted  repealed  41037 in its entirety former  41037 pertained to promotion of employees and carried no history note salary reviews a when opportunities the recruitment selection appointment and promotion of employees shall be in such a manner as to promote equal employment opportunity for all persons without regard to race age color creed sex national origin ancestry religious affiliation political affiliation or disability vacant positions a department heads shall be responsible for notifying the personnel director of vacant or soon to be vacant authorized positions in their department the notification shall include the class title and salary range the city manager shall review the information and determine whether the vacancy should be filled b as far as practical vacancies shall be filled by promotion of employees of the city all vacancies shall be announced to city employees  a vacancy announcement shall be posted for at least three 3 work days in a specified location for each department c in the event that an employee continues his employment as a deemed retiree and remains in the same position as he is then employed no vacancy occurs for such position as contemplated by this section and a vacancy announcement is not required  21604 recruitment for vacant positions all fulltime vacancies shall be publicized by the personnel director by posting announcements and by other such means as necessary to assure obtaining well qualified candidates for the positions the announcement shall specify the title and salary range of the vacant position any minimum qualification requirements manner of making application the final date on which applications shall be received and other pertinent information every reasonable effort shall be made to publicize vacancies so that all interested persons are informed and qualified persons are attracted to compete application forms application shall be made on the city application forms the forms shall include information covering training experience and other pertinent factors all applications shall be signed by the person applying disqualification the personnel director may remove from further consideration the application of an applicant who 1 does not meet the minimum qualifications established for the position  2 has a health handicap that would prevent satisfactory performance of the duties of the position  3 has made false statements of material fact or practiced deception in this application  4 is addicted to the habitual use of drugs or intoxicating liquors  5 has an unsatisfactory employment record of such a nature as to demonstrate unsuitability for employment  6 has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude  or 7 has failed to submit his application within the prescribed time limit selection a the personnel director shall review all applications for employment to determine whether the applicant meets the established standards for employment the information may be required as is necessary to make such determination when appropriate examinations may be used which may be written or oral or a combination of these the tests shall be practical in character and shall relate to the duties and responsibilities of the position for which the applicant is being examined b applicants meeting the employment standards will be referred to the employing department head by the personnel director the personnel director may reasonably limit the number of applicants referred to the department head  however the department head may request that all applications of persons applying for the job be referred to him the department head shall make a selection from the applicants referred and shall notify the personnel director of his recommendation as soon as he makes a decision appointment the city manager or personnel director shall review and either accept or reject the recommendation of the department head as to the applicant to be employed if the applicant recommended by the department head is rejected the department head shall make another recommendation to the city manager or personnel director upon the failure or refusal of the department head to make a recommendation or another recommendation if previous recommendation is rejected the city manager may select the person considered to be the most qualified to fill the position for employment with the city when an applicant is selected the city manager or personnel director shall authorize or direct an offer of employment  81781 emergency appointment when an emergency involving the serious impairment of the public business makes it impossible to fill a vacant position by normal procedure the department head with the approval of the personnel director and the city manager may appoint any qualified person to the position on a temporary basis in order to prevent stoppage of public business or loss or serious inconvenience to the public such an appointment shall be for a period not to exceed thirtyone 31 days during which time the normal selection procedures would be followed in order to fill the position permanently   reserved editors note  adopted nov 17 200 repealed former  410481 in its entirety which pertained to the employment of deemed retirees and derived from  adopted feb 16 2004 employment of relatives it has been determined to be in the best interest of and is therefore the policy of the city not to employ any person in a position in which such person directly supervises or is directly supervised by a member of an employees immediate family as used herein immediate family shall mean any person holding a relationship with a present employee of the city of husband wife son daughter brother or sister and to father mother fatherinlaw motherinlaw sisterinlaw brotherinlaw soninlaw or daughterinlaw this policy applies to promotions demotions transfers reinstatements and new employees 1 if two 2 employees marry while working with the city then one shall not thereafter be in a supervisory capacity over the other if two 2 employees are married and one is in a supervisory capacity over the other or attains a supervisory position while working in the same department one must transfer within thirty 30 days of the date of their marriage to another department if both are to continue working for the city subject to the approval of the city manager the two 2 employees may agree which would prefer to transfer in the event the city manager does not approve the agreement between the two 2 employees or the two 2 employees are not able to agree upon which should transfer the employee with the shortest seniority in the department will be required to transfer in the event there has been no position available for transfer at the end of the thirty 30 days the transferring employee shall be required to take a leave of absence without pay unless such employee has accrued vacation or compensatory time and shall have five 5 months thereafter within which to effectuate such transfer to the first available position if said additional fivemonth period expires without said transferring employee transferring to another position all continued rights of employment shall cease if or when said transferring employee is on a leave without pay pending transfer all benefits of the city shall cease during the period of said leave and not recommence thereafter until such transferring employee resumes employment with the city 2 if a city institutes a reorganization which changes departmental boundaries where immediate family members would be supervising or is directly supervised by another member of his or her immediate family one of such employees must transfer to another department within thirty 30 days of the date of the reorganization if both are to continue working with the city subject to the approval of the city manager the two 2 employees may agree which would prefer to transfer in the event the city manager does not approve the agreement between the two 2 employees or the two 2 employees are unable to agree upon which should transfer the employee in the lowest pay grade in the new department will be required to transfer if in the event there has been no position available for transfer at the end of the thirty 30 days the transferring employee shall be transferred to any position designated by the city manager to the highest pay grade available for such position if such transfer results in a reduction in pay for such individual  provided that said transferring employees pay does not exceed the pay of an employee in the lower pay grade with like seniority of the transferring employee thereafter the transferring employee may transfer to any other department in the city provided said employee may not resume a position in the department wherein an immediate family member holds a supervisory position  81682   81588 objective of probationary period the probationary period shall be regarded as an integral part of the selection process and shall be utilized for closely observing the employees work for securing the most effective adjustment of a new employee to this position and for rejecting any employee whose performance is not satisfactory employees serving their probationary period do not have appeal rights unless there is alleged discrimination because of political affiliation religious affiliation race age color creed sex national origin ancestry or disability employees who are separated from the city service prior to the completion of their probationary service shall receive no vacation pay duration the probationary period shall be for a minimum of six 6 months to a maximum of twelve 12 months the length of the probationary period for each class shall be established by the personnel director with the approval of the city manager if a department head requests an extension of an established probationary period prior to fifteen 15 days before expiration the personnel director with the approval of the city manager may extend the probationary period of a particular employee up to three 3 months beyond the end of the normal probationary period evaluation of performance after the employee has completed onehalf of his established probationary period the department head shall report to the personnel director in writing his observation of the employees work and his judgment as to whether or not the employees services have been satisfactory during the probationary period the employees supervisor will tell the employee when he is not performing satisfactorily at least fifteen 15 days prior to the expiration of an employees probationary period the department head shall notify the personnel director in writing whether or not an employee has satisfactorily completed his probationary period dismissal during the probationary period the department head may remove an employee with or without cause the department head shall immediately report the removal to the personnel director and to the employee and shall state his reasons employees serving their probationary period do not have appeal rights unless there is alleged discrimination because of political affiliation age race color creed sex religion national origin ancestry or disability promotional appointments the probationary period shall be used in connection with promotional appointments in the same manner as it is used for entrance appointments if an employee is removed from his position during his probationary period following a promotion he shall be entitled to his former position type of separation separations of employees from positions in the classified service shall be designated as one of the following and shall be accomplished in the manner indicated resignation compulsory resignation layoff disability death retirement and dismissal city equipment at the time of separation and prior to final payment all records assets and other items of city property in the employees custody shall be transferred to his department head and certification to this effect shall be signed by the employee any amount due because of shortage in the above shall be withheld from the employees final compensation rights of employees employees who separate shall receive payment for all earned salary and certify compensatory time subject to deductions as outlined in section 41056 of this chapter and those employees who have completed their probationary service shall also receive payment for all earned annual leave resignation to resign in good standing an employee shall give notice in writing to his department head at least ten 10 working days prior to the effective date of his resignation normally failure to comply with this rule shall be entered on the service record of the employee and may result in a deduction from accrued vacation pay compulsory resignation any employee who without valid reason fails to report to work for three 3 consecutive work days without authorized leave shall be separated from the payroll and reported as a compulsory resignation layoff the city manager may identify numbers of positions by job title to be vacated which will result in the layoff of an employee in the classified service when he deemed it necessary because of shortage of funds or work or other material changes in the duties or organization or for related reasons which do not reflect discredit upon the service of the employee when any positions so vacated are refilled within a period of two 2 years following a layoff the persons removed therefrom if available and able to efficiently perform the duties of such positions shall be first entitled to be restored to the position the layoff of employees shall be made in inverse order on the basis of length of service in the job title  41904 disability an employee may be separated for disability when he cannot perform the required duties or when continuance on the job is a danger to himself or others action may be initiated by the employee at his expense or the city at its expense but in all cases it must be supported by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager an employee agrees upon request by the city to submit to examination by a doctor of the citys choice and agrees to cooperate fully with the examination death when a full time employee dies while in the service of the city all compensation due in accordance with section 41057 of this chapter shall be paid to the legal representative of the employees estate or any other properly designated individual retirement a when an employee meets the conditions of retirement set forth in the employees retirement system he or she may after providing ninety 90 days prior written notice of intent to retire retire and shall receive such compensation due in accordance with the provisions of sections 41057 and 41078f of this chapter to the extent any employees notice of intent to retire is less than the minimum amount prescribed above the amount by which such employees notice violates the above minimum time frame shall be reduced or deducted from any entitled compensation pursuant to the provisions of sections 41057 and 41078f b the minimum time frames for notice of intent to retire prescribed in a above may be waived or reduced in the sole discretion of the city  3983 dismissal right to answer the charge and the employees right to appeal as provided in section 41013 of this  31708 types of disciplinary action the following provisions shall govern disciplinary actions affecting employees in the classified service a department head subject to the appeal rights of the employee shall have the following alternatives for disciplinary action 1 a department head may submit a written reprimand to an employee when an oral warning has not resulted in the expected improvement  or when more severe initial action is warranted copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager 2 a department head may for cause suspend without pay an employee in his department for up to ten 10 days a written statement specifically setting forth reasons for suspension shall be furnished to the employee copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager with the prior approval of the city manager the length of the suspension may be extended 3 with the prior approval of the city manager a department head may reduce the salary of an employee within the range provided in the pay plan or demote the employee for cause to a lower class a written statement of the reasons for the action shall be furnished to the employee copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager  12285 reasons for disciplinary action listed below are some reasons which might be cause for disciplinary action referred to in section 41065 of this chapter but disciplinary action is not limited to the offenses listed 1 being convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude  2 being absent without an excused or excusable leave  3 excessive tardiness which is defined as that absence from work which interferes with the efficient performance of job responsibilities and work production  4 abuse of sick leave which is defined as that absence from work which interferes with the efficient performance of job responsibilities and work production  5 inefficient negligent incompetent or total failure in performance of ones duties  6 careless negligent or improper use of city property or equipment  7 willfully giving false statements to supervisors  8 violation of city ordinances administrative regulations or departmental rules  9 being under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs when reporting for work or partaking of such things while on duty except that prescribed medication may be taken within the limits set by a physician as long as it is medically necessary  or 10 instigation of participation in or leadership of a strike work stoppage slowdown or artificial restriction of productive work emergency relief from duty if determined to be in the best interest of the city a nondepartment head supervisor may relieve an employee from duty for disciplinary purposes relief from duty shall be only from the time the action is initiated by the supervisor until the beginning of the employees next scheduled work period the supervisor shall report the action and circumstance to the department head who shall review the action and initiate any further disciplinary action which may be warranted policy of grievances and appeals the most effective accomplishment of the work of the city requires prompt consideration and equitable adjustment of employee grievances it is the desire of the city to adjust grievances informally and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise however it is recognized that there may be grievances which will be resolved only after a formal appeal and review no employee shall be disciplined or discriminated against in any way because of use of the grievance procedure definition a grievance is a complaint made by an employee concerning the interpretation of these rules and regulations or departmental work rules or working conditions reserved editors note  adopted  repealed decision and the reasons for it within five 5 working days after receipt of the employees grievance c if the employee is dissatisfied with the department heads decision he may obtain a review by the city manager by submitting a request in writing within five 5 working days following the receipt of the department heads decision the city manager shall make such investigation and conduct such hearings as he deems necessary and shall within ten 10 working days after the receipt of the employees request for review inform the department head and employee in writing of his findings and changes overtime a overtime department heads are authorized to grant overtime at the rate of time and onehalf  when the work being performed is mission critical or as required by law any overtime which is not preauthorized by action of city council must be justified in writing as mission critical overtime is paid after forty 40 hours per week for all general employees and police personnel overtime is paid after two hundred twelve 212 hours in the designated twentyeightday work period for fire sworn personnel as in accordance with the fair labor standards act 207k exemption 1 mission critical mission critical overtime is defined as overtime necessary to prevent disruption of essential city services these services include but are not limited to the following a sewer or waterline breaks during nonworking hours of assigned crews b poweroutages as a result of tree limbs broken poles storm damage etc c stormrelated emergencies for sanding of streets clearing roadways or restoring basic city services d shortage of manpower which necessitates calling in personnel to prevent the closing down of emergency equipment e shortage of manpower which necessitate calling in additional personnel to prevent the reduction of emergency services f street or bridge caveins or collapse which would effect the safety of the public g seasonal leaf pickup when determined that not working overtime would disrupt collection schedules h revenue critical functions needed to maintain cashflow and schedule of hearing mandates in the area of court services 2 legal requirements under federal law fire personnel must be paid overtime after an average of fiftythree 53 hours per week of work time this does not sufficiently cover the hours to maintain a twentyfourhour operation when minimal staffing levels to do not allow time off overtime will be paid to meet federal guidelines 3 assignment of overtime a assignment of overtime must be managed such that the work is performed by the least number of employees needed to accomplish the task required and should be performed by the employees at the lowest rate of pay who have the required skills and experience to perform the mission critical tasks b overtime paid per employee must be documented with justification for the overtime as mission critical and this documentation must be made available upon request for management review b compensatory time 1 for employees hired on or after  compensatory time or time off in lieu of overtime may be granted for overtime hours worked these hours worked over the maximum regular hours allowed in each work period forty 40 hours for employees except fire personnel will be accrued at the rate of time and onehalf  of the employees regular pay rate for employees hired before  compensatory time may be taken in place of overtime at the employees discretion 2 employees who accrue overtime earned as comptime may be required to take comptime at a time when city services will not be seriously affected as determined by the department head the maximum accrued comptime per employee is two hundred forty 240 hours for general employees and four hundred eighty 480 hours for fire and police personnel all overtime earned after the maximum comptime accrual is reached must be paid as overtime pay any accrued and unused comptime must be paid in full when the employee ceases to be iii 1713 funding trust fund a all contributions made pursuant to this plan by the employer and participants shall be paid into the trust fund to be held managed invested and distributed in accordance section 41118  501 contributions a as a condition of participation in the plan all participants shall contribute to the plan these contributions will be deposited by the employer in the trust fund each pay period effective  each participant shall contribute to the trust fund at an annual rate of six 6 percent of his compensation by means of regular payroll deductions hereinafter the participant contributions effective  the employer will pick up participant contributions such participant contributions will be treated as employer contributions in accordance with internal revenue h and any treasury regulations promulgated thereunder employer pickup of participant contributions shall be effectuated by reducing the compensation of each participant by six 6 percent no participant shall have the option to receive the pickup contributions directly instead of having such contributions paid by the employer to the trust fund b subject to section 41118e the employer shall contribute to the trust fund monthly such amounts as from time to time are estimated by the actuary to be sufficient upon an actuarially sound basis to provide the balance of accrued retirement benefits under the plan not provided by participant contributions and earnings c effective  the employer shall contribute to the trust fund at an annual rate of sixteen 16 percent of each participants compensation or such other amount as recommended by the actuary and adopted by the employer such contributions may be made in cash or in property which is an authorized investment of the trust fund as provided in the trust agreement or in a combination of cash and such property d the expenses of administering the plan including such items as the accounting actuarial legal and trustees fees shall be paid by the trust fund e notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary the employer shall have the right in its sole and final discretion at any time or from time to time to discontinue or temporarily suspend for a definite or indefinite period its contributions under the plan without any liability whatsoever upon the complete discontinuance of contributions by the employer the rights of participants shall be nonforfeitable in accordance with and to the extent provided in subsection 41333c  502 pension board appointment resignation removal a there is hereby established a pension board procedure the board shall act by agreement of a majority of its members either by vote at a meeting or in writing without a meeting by such action it may authorize one 1 or more of its members or the plan administrator to execute documents on its behalf and direct the trustee in the performance of its duties as related to the powers and duties of the board specified below  and the trustee upon written notification of such authorization shall accept and rely upon such documents and directions until notified in writing that the authorization has been revoked or changed by the board a member of the board who is also a participant shall not vote or act upon any matter directly affecting any of his benefits under the plan in the event of a deadlock or other situation which prevents agreement of a majority of the board members the matter shall be decided by the city council  602 powers and duties the board shall have the power and duty to do all things necessary or convenient to the plan andor trust agreement and its construction thereof in good faith and act in the best interests of the participants 3 correct any defect or supply any omission or reconcile any inconsistency in the plan in such manner and to such extent as it shall deem expedient to carry the same into effect 4 determine all questions that shall arise under the plan including directions to and questions submitted by the trustee on all matters necessary for it to properly discharge its duties  provided however that in no event shall the board have any authority to direct any money manager or the trustee in the investment of the trust fund 5 the board shall select a custodian who will issue all benefit and expense payments  603 benefit application and claims procedure a participants and any benefit due him under the plan b within ninety 90 days after receipt of such an application the plan administrator shall notify the applicant of the boards decision if special circumstances require an extension of time the plan administrator shall notify the applicant of such circumstances within ninety 90 days after receipt of the application and the plan administrator shall thereafter circumstances require an extension of time the plan administrator shall notify the applicant of such circumstances within sixty 60 days after receipt of the request for review and the plan cessation of operations by the employer with no successor or assign which shall adopt the plan and become a party to the trust agreement c nonforfeitable rights and order of priorities upon termination of the plan or upon complete discontinuance of contributions by the employer the rights of all participants to any accrued retirement benefits or to refund of participants contributions to the date of such termination or discontinuance to the extent then funded shall be nonforfeitable upon such termination or discontinuance there shall be set aside in a separate account an amount estimated by the board to be adequate to defray all costs and charges including those of legal counsel actuary and trustee associated with the plan termination from the trust fund remaining the amount of the accrued retirement benefits shall be deemed to have been funded in the following order of priorities 1 all participants contributions with interest payable under the plan to the date of termination of the plan 2 all participants who prior to the termination of the plan have retired or died or have elected phased retirement and who or their beneficiaries are already receiving benefits and participants who are continuing employment under the delayed retirement provisions 3 all participants who prior to termination of the plan were eligible for early or normal but not delayed retirement benefits 4 all participants who prior to termination of the plan were one hundred 100 percent vested in their benefits 5 all remaining participants with accrued retirement benefits 6 all contingent beneficiaries entitled to death benefits only upon the deaths of participants who are living at the time the plan is terminated benefits payable under any of the items listed above shall be properly adjusted to reflect any benefits payable under any prior item in the event the trust fund is insufficient to fully fund the accrued retirement benefits to the date of such termination or discontinuance for all participants in any class then such accrued retirement benefits shall be deemed to have been funded in the proportion which the then actuarially determined present value of the accrued retirement benefits for each participant in such class bears to the then actuarially determined present value of the accrued retirement benefits for all participants in such class d methods of satisfying obligations upon termination of the plan the board shall determine and so direct the trustee the method from among the following methods of discharging and satisfying all obligations in the order of priorities specified above on behalf of participants 1 by continuation of the trust and the payment therefrom of benefits as they become due in accordance with the provisions of the plan in effect immediately prior to its termination  or 2 by annuities payable media of annuity contracts purchased from an insurance company  or 3 by the liquidation and distribution of the assets of the trust fund  or 4 by any combination of such methods e repayment to employer after the satisfaction of all liabilities under the plan any overpayments made by the employer into the trust fund as a result of erroneous actuarial computations shall be repaid to the employer  702   miscellaneous small benefits in the event that any retirement benefit provided under the plan is payable in an amount domestic relations order the plan administrator must comply with a qualified domestic relations order 1 a domestic relations order is any judgment decree or order including approval of a property settlement agreement made pursuant to a state domestic relations law including a community property law which relates to the provision of child support alimony payments or marital property rights to a spouse former spouse child or other dependent of a participant alternate payee 2 a qualified domestic relations order is a domestic relations order which a creates or recognizes the existence of an mailing address if any of the participant and the name and mailing address of each alternate payee covered by the order b the amount of percentage of the participants benefits to be paid by the plan to each alternate payee or the manner in which such amount or percentage is to be determined c the number of payments or the period to which the order applies and d each plan to which the order applies  and c does not require the plan to a provide any type or form of benefit or any option not otherwise provided under the plan b provide increased benefits determined on the basis of actuarial value c pay benefits to an alternate payee that are required to be paid to another alternate payee under another order previously determined to be a qualified domestic relations order or d pay any benefits to any alternate payee before the earlier of the participants termination of employment or attainment of his earliest retirement age 3 after receipt of a domestic relations order the plan administrator shall 1 promptly notify the affected participant and any alternate payee of the receipt of such order and the plans procedure for determining the qualified status of domestic relations orders and 2 within a reasonable period after receipt of such order determine whether the order is a qualified domestic relations order and notify the participant and each alternate payee of such determination 4 the board shall establish a procedure to determine the qualified status of domestic relations order and to administer plan distributions in accordance with qualified domestic relations orders such procedure shall be in writing shall include a provision specifying the notification requirements enumerated in the preceding paragraph shall permit an alternate payee to designate a representative for receipt of communications from the plan administrator and shall include such other provision as the plan administrator determines consistent with a13 and 414p 5 during any period in which the issue of whether a domestic relations order is a qualified domestic relations order is being determined by the plan administrator a court of competent jurisdiction or otherwise the plan administrator shall segregate in a separate account under the plan the amount if any which would have been payable to the alternate payee during such period if the order had been determined to be a qualified domestic relations order  805 persons under legal disability in the event any benefit is payable to a minor or other person under legal disability the board in its discretion may determine public body an activity policy or practice of the employer a coemployee or another employer that the employee reasonably believes is in violation of a law or a rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to law or in the case of an employee who is licensed or certified health care professional reasonably believes constitutes improper quality of patient care  b provides information to or testifies patient care  c discloses threatens to disclose or is about to disclose to a supervisor or to a public body an activity policy or practice of the employer a coemployee or another employer that the employee reasonably believes is incompatible with a clear mandate of public policy concerning the public health safety or welfare or protection of the environment  d assists or participates in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of the law  or e objects to opposes or refuses to participate in any activity policy or practice which the employee reasonably believes 1 is in violation of a law or a rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to law or if the employee is a licensed or certified health care professional constitutes improper quality of patient care  2 is fraudulent or criminal  or 3 is incompatible with a clear mandate of public policy concerning public health safety or welfare or protection of the environment  12103 forum upon a violation of any of the provision of this the validity of any claim under this act specified in the suit  12103 burden of proof a violation of this statute has occurred only if the employee demonstrates by a preponderance of the evidence that any behavior described in was a contributing factor in the retaliatory action alleged in the complaint by the employee however relief may not be ordered under if the employer demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence that it would have taken the same unfavorable personnel action the alleged retaliatory action in the absence of such behavior  12103 remedies all remedies available in common law recognition is approved this analysis shall include the number of employees affected administrative costs and any other factors deemed necessary by the city manager if recognition of the employee such deduction of dues the finance director will remit the balance of dues collected to the employee organization together with a list of names of employees from whom the dues were collected as soon standard and customary activities subject to the employees compliance with east points leave policy or prior city councils approval for attending east point functions c no employee shall be required as a condition of employment with east point to become a member of any employee organization  62104 meet and confer a meetings 1 when an employee organization requests a meeting with the city the employee organizations on employment related matters and such representatives shall have access to city employees during nonwork time and in nonwork areas including break rooms and cafeterias such problems arising from a a disagreement with application of city policy or practice  b a disagreement with application of department policy or practice  or c a workplace conflict with supervision that has direct impact on the workplace 3 meet and confer for employee input into policy a representation from recognized employee organizations shall meet and confer with the designated representatives of the city on a monthly basis or as needed in order to discuss policy issues which affect employees concerns hours and the other conditions of employment b the participants in these monthly meetings of the dispute resolution procedure or personnel regulations c official leave activities which are not contemplated by the employee organization ordinance and would not be charged to official leave offficers and employees definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section 1 claim means any assertion of damage or demand for action or payment presented to or against an employee prior to the institution of a proceeding this term shall apply where the claimant asserts personal liability for damages arising out of the performance of duties or the claim is in any way connected with the performance of duties whether based on negligence violation of contract rights or violation of constitutional law common law or statutory rights whether federal state or local 2 employee means the mayor and members of the east point city council employees of the city and appointed city officials including members of city commissions councils and boards the term shall not include independent vendor or contractors doing business with the city or members of independent or state chartered boards and commissions 3 proceeding includes any claim instituted in or before any court or administrative agency of this state any other state or the united states  51605 construction nothing contained herein shall be deemed to constitute a waiver by the city or by any of its employees of the sovereign immunity official immunity or any other immunity afforded under the constitution and laws of the state of georgia or of the united states the city and its employees specifically reserve the right to assert immunity in response to any claim or proceeding and this ordinance shall not construed so as to require the city or any employee to pay any sums based on claims from which the city and its employees are immune  51605 defense of employees a whenever any claim is made or any proceeding is instituted against an employee the city shall be authorized upon written request to provide for the employees defense unless otherwise limited by the terms of this article in terms of providing a defense the city shall direct the city attorney or engage outside counsel of the citys choosing to provide a legal defense for the employee the costs for providing legal defense shall be borne by the city b the provisions of this article shall not apply unless the employee provides notice in writing of any claim or proceeding to the city manager within thirty 30 days after the employee has notice of a claim andor within five 5 days after the employee has been served with process in any proceeding c nothing contained in this article shall be construed to confer to any employee a legal right or entitlement to a defense by the city as to any claim or proceeding  51605 grounds for refusal of defense a the city may refuse to provide for the defense of a claim or proceeding brought against any employee if it determines that any one or more of the following conditions exists 1 the act or omission forming the basis of the claim or proceeding did not arise in the course and scope of the employees duties for the city  2 the employee acted or failed to act because of actual or intentional misconduct fraud corruption malice or bad faith  3 the claim or proceeding is criminal in nature or the employee acted or failed to act in such manner as to constitute a criminal act  4 the employee acted or failed to act as a result of or at a time when the employees selfindulgence substantially impaired the employees judgment including without limitation an employee being intoxicated or under the influence of illegal narcotics while acting on behalf of the city  5 the employee acted or failed to act except in under extenuating circumstances directly contrary to advice of the city attorney or safety personnel  6 the employee fails to cooperate in the defense of the claim or proceeding or knowingly supplies false information regarding the claim or proceeding  7 the employee acted or failed to act in willful disregard of city policy or the specific instructions of the city council or the employees supervisor  or 8 provision of a defense against the claim or proceeding would not be in the best interest of the city b the determinations required by subsection a of this section shall be made solely by the city council upon the advice of the city attorney and upon due consideration of any internal investigation the council may require the city attorney may commence an initial representation and defense of an employee if the claim or proceeding requires that action be taken before the next scheduled meeting of council and the city attorney concludes in his or her discretion that the claim or proceeding would satisfy the criteria for defense by the city at any time prior to or after the approval or assumption of the defense the city may discontinue or refuse to provide the defense of an employee if the council determines that any of the grounds for refusal set forth in this section exists or has come to exist c upon approval by city council of the defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee the matter shall be referred to the city attorney or an outside attorney for disposition d nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from providing a defense against claims or proceedings where there is a conflict between one employee or group of employees as compared with another employee or group of employees if two or more employees or groups of employees are involved in a claim or proceeding and the interest of one employee or group of employees conflicts with the interest of another employee or group of employees city council shall approve or refuse to provide a defense to the respective employees or groups of employees in accordance the terms of subsection a e if the city approves providing a defense to two 2 or more employees or groups of employees involved in a claim or proceeding and the interest of one employee or group of employees conflicts with the interest of another employee or group of employees council shall specify which employee or group of employees shall be represented by the city attorney and shall authorize the other employee or group of employees to retain separate counsel at the expense of the city  provided however that the selection and compensation of such separate counsel shall be subject to the prior approval of the city council  51605 payment of judgments and settlements a where defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee is provided in accordance with this article all final judgments awarded in courts of competent jurisdiction against the employee or any amount payable under a settlement of such claim or proceedings shall be paid by the city as hereinafter provided all compromises of claims or proceedings governed by this article shall be approved by city council upon recommendation of the city attorney or outside counsel as the case may be b notwithstanding the foregoing payment of judgments and claims shall be limited as follows 1 no sum will be paid under the provisions of this division for punitive or exemplary damages 2 no sum shall be paid under the provisions of this division unless the claimant unconditionally releases the employee and the city from any and all claims causes of action or judgments arising from the subject claim or proceeding 3 any claim or proceeding as to which insurance is provided by the city is specifically excluded from the operation of this article c nothing contained in this article shall be construed to confer to any employee a legal right or entitlement to have the city pay any settlement or any judgment fine fee or cost rendered on a claim or proceeding  51605 chapter 2  city property funds and labor control expenditures this article shall control the expenditure of all city funds from all sources
